item.title: Multiple-use protected areas are critical to equitable and effective conservation
item.dc:creator: Adams, Cahuvenet, Stoudmann, Gurney, Brockington, Kuempel
item.description:
The published paper is available on-line.

Given their substantial contributions to meeting area-based targets, we review evidence of multiple-use protected areas in meeting global policy goals. We found that multiple-use protected areas can be effective in conserving biodiversity and are more likely to be under equitable governance arrangements than their strict counterparts. Our results show that multiple-use and other protected areas provide important environmental and socio-economic benefits that are needed to achieve the 2030 target.

Media coverage

item.title: Biological life history and farming scenarios of marine aquaculture help reduce wild marine fishing pressure
item.dc:creator: Froehlich, Montgomery, Williams, O'Hara, Kuempel, Halpern
item.description:
The published paper is available on-line.

This paper explored capture-based and domesticated auaculture based on wild seed reliance to assess which forms of aquaculture coudl support seafood production and greater wild biomass.

item.title: Integrated watershed management solutions for healthy coastal ecosystems and people
item.dc:creator: Wakwella, Wenger, Jenkins, Lamb, Kuempel, Claar, Carbin, Falinski, Rivera, Grantham, Jupiter
item.description:
The published paper is available on-line.

This review summarises the evidence of impacts to coastal ecosystems, particularly coral reefs, from sediments, nutrients, chemicals and pathogens entering coastal zones through surface and groundwater. We also assess how these pollutants affect the health of coastal human populations through: (1) enhanced transmission of infectious diseases; (2) reduced food availability and nutritional deficit from decline of fisheries associated with degraded habitat; and (3) food poisoning from consumption of contaminated seafood.

Media coverage

item.title: Sedimentation sifted out of pollution priorities
item.dc:creator: kuempel
item.description:
The published letter is available on-line.

The Kunming-Montreal Global Biodiversity Framework (GBF) includes four goals and 23 targets to halt biodiversity loss and restore natural ecosystems by 2030 (1). The list includes goals to reduce pollution from sources such as plastics and nutrients (Target 7) but overlooks sediment—a key driver of poor water quality that threatens freshwater and marine ecosystems. To conserve aquatic environments, the global community must prioritize explicit indicators and commitments to reduce excess sediment.

Media coverage

item.title: Feed drives land-sea overlap of the global cumulative environmental pressure of farmed chicken and salmon
item.dc:creator: Kuempel, Frazier, Verstaen, Rayner, Blanchard, Bouwman, Cottrell, Froehlich, Gephart, Jacobsen, McIntyre, Metian, Nash, Tobben, Williams, Halpern
item.description:
The published paper is available on-line.

This paper assesses and compares the environmental footprint of farming industrial broiler chickens and farmed salmonids to identify opportunities to reduce environmental pressures. You can find an accompanying summary article in The Conversation.

Media coverage

item.title: The environmental footprint of global food production
item.dc:creator: Halpern, Frazier, Verstaen...Kuempel, et al. 2022
item.description:
The published paper and code are available on-line.

We quantified pressures resulting from food production (cover 99% of food produced) including greenhouse gas emissions, freshwater use, nutrient pollution, and spatial disturbance. We then created a cumulative index to identify hotspots and relative efficiencies in production between sectors and locations.

item.title: Rights and representation support justice across aquatic food systems
item.dc:creator: Hicks, Gephart, Koehn....Kuempel..et al.,
item.description:
The published paper and code are available on-line.

Blue foods support diets and livelihoods for billiones of people, but are unequal in their benefits. We assess economic, political and social barriers impacting participation in blue food produciton across 195 countries and found trade-offs between wealth-generating and welfare-sutaining benefits can threaten food security.

Media coverage

item.title: Global fishing between jurisdictions with unequal fisheries management
item.dc:creator: Klein, Kuempel, Watson, Teneva, Coll and Mora
item.description:
The published paper and code are available on-line.

Fisheries can cause environmental degradation. These impacts can be displaced when one country fishes in another country’s waters. This may be particularly problematic when the fished country has less ability to manage it’s fisheries or marine resources than the fishiing country. We quantified the extent of “unequal” fishing displacement between countries to assess the countries who participate the most in this practice and the countries that potential are the most impacted.

Media coverage

item.title: Demystifying ecological connectivity for actional spatial conservation planning
item.dc:creator: Beger, Metaxas, Balbar, McGowan, Daigle, Kuempel, Treml, Possingham
item.description:
The published paper is available on-line.

There is a disconnect between global high-level conservation goals and onthe-ground actions such as maintaining ecosystem services or planning for protected areas, particularly for connectivity goals. We show how connectivity can be included in conservation planning objectives and connected to high-level goals.

item.title: The impact of excessive protein consumption on human wastewater nitrogen loading of US waters
item.dc:creator: Almaraz, Kuempel, Salter, Halpern, B.S.
item.description:

Nitrogen is a waste product of protein consumption that can impact the environment. We quantified how reducing protein consumption to recommended rates may reduce nitrogen loading in the United States.

item.title: Global rarity of intact coastal regions
item.dc:creator: Williams, Watson, Beyer, Klein, Montgomery, Runting, Roberson, Halpern, Grantham, Kuempel, Frazier, Venter, Wenger
item.description:
The published paper is available on-line.

We describe a method for combining terrestrial and marine cumulative impact maps. We then use this to identify coastal areas with relatively less human impact globally.

item.title: Identifying management opportunities to combat climate, land, and marine threats across less climate exposed coral reefs
item.dc:creator: Kuempel, Tulloch, Giffin, Simmons, Hagger, Phua, Hoegh-Guldberg
item.description:
The published paper and data are available on-line.

We used the marine cumulative human footprint data to assess major threats to coral reefs that have been identified as being less exposed to climate change. We then reviewed common management practices and policies to explore the potential commitment of each country in reducing these threats.

item.title: Predicted protected area downsizing impedes conservation progress across terrestrial ecoregions in the tropics and subtropics
item.dc:creator: Kuempel, Chauvenet, Symes, Possingham
item.description:
The published paper is available on-line.

We explored how protected area downsizing impacts conservation target achievement by using the protection equality and mean target achievement metrics. We found mean target achievement always decreases with downsizing, and downsizing often occurs in underrepresented habitats which decreases protection equality.

item.title: An informed thought experiment exploring the potential for a paradigm shift in aquatic food production
item.dc:creator: Kuempel, Froehlich, Halpern
item.description:
The published paper is available on-line.

In this work, we developed a thought experiment to compare the shift from hunting and gathering on land to the potential shift from fishing to fish farming in sea. We discuss similarities and differences which may impact a complete transition to aquaculture in the future.

item.title: Time to rethink tropic levels in aquaculture policy
item.dc:creator: Cottrell, Metian, Froehlich, Blanchard, Jacobsen, McIntyre, Nash, Williams Bouwman, Gephart, Kuempel, Moran, Troell, Halpern
item.description:
The published paper and data are available on-line.

We explored how the trophic level of farmed species has shifted in recent years due to feed composition - and implications of this in using trophic level as a sustainability measure.

This article was honored as a Sena de Silva paper which recognises high quality articles that excel in one, or more of the following qualities: i) Novelty and originality, ii) likelihood of direct positive impacts for the aquaculture sector, with keen focus on any of, or all three: environmental sustainability, economic viability, and social responsibility, iii) overall quality of scientific reasonings coupled with real-world applicability.

Media coverage
